results.title: Covered Wagon
results.creator_credit: James Cruze and Famous Players-Lasky Corporation
results.brief_description: Recounts the journey by the men and women who left the Mississippi and Ohio valleys in 1848 to migrate to Oregon. Most of this Western epic was shot on location and captures the beauty of America’s vast frontier landscape. Essentially a romantic drama focusing on the leader of a wagon train who falls in love with the daughter of another wagon train leader. Before he can win her heart, he must clear himself of false cattle theft charges. During the journey, the wagon trains are exposed to forces of nature and the wrath of native Americans Indians defending their land against intruders. Script by Jack Cunningham based on the novel by Emerson Hough. Photographed by Karl Brown. Edited by Dorothy Arzner. Starring Alan Hale, J. Warren Kerrigan, Charles Ogle and Lois Wilson. Based on the novel by Emerson Hough.

results.title: A Cottage on Dartmoor
results.creator_credit: Anthony Asquith and British Instructional Films
results.brief_description: Released with a synchronised music disc in 1930, but essentially regarded as a silent film. Anthony Asquith last ‘silent’ film was considered a rival to Hitchcock’s ‘Blackmail’. Presents the unrequited love of a barber’s assistant for a manicurist and the results of his jealous rage when she becomes engaged to a customer, relayed in a long flash-back during his attempted escape from Dartmoor. Cast includes: Norah Baring, Uno Henning, Hans Schlettow and Judd Green. Photographed by Stanley Rodwell. Story by Herbert C. Price.

results.title: Conquest of Everest
results.creator_credit: Grahame Tharp, Leon Clore, John Taylor, Group 3 and Countrymen Productions
results.brief_description: A record of the successful Everest expedition in 1953. Beginning with a brief account of earlier expeditions, this film shows the months of preparation, the arrival of the expedition party in Nepal, the hiring of the sherpas in Katmandu, the progress from one camp to another and the final assault by Hillary and Tenzing. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Burma victory
results.creator_credit: Roy Boulting, David Macdonald and Army Film Unit
results.brief_description: Compilation of footage covering the Burma campaign against the Japanese between 1942 and 1945. For censorship reasons this campaign was given very little newsreel coverage and the footage was assembled into an absorbing narrative. Footage taken by British, Indian and American Combat Cameramen of South-East Asia Command.

results.title: The Boy Kumasenu
results.creator_credit: Sean Graham, John Hollingsworth and Gold Coast Film Unit
results.brief_description: Dramatised documentary of a young African boy, Kumasenu, making his way unaided from the tribal world into the twentieth century. He has known no life other than that of a quiet fishing village. Wrongly accused of bringing bad luck to his people he becomes an outcast and an easy prey to the temptations of the city life of which his flash friend Agboh thinks so highly. Until helped by new friends, life for him is bewildering and dangerous.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sean Graham, John Hollingsworth and Gold Coast Film Unit

results.title: The Battle of Russia
results.creator_credit: Anatole Litvak, Frank Capra and United States. Office of War Information. Overseas Operations Branch
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Why we fight”.
This epic film unfolds the great history of Russia, and the defeat of Hitler’s Nazi armies. The depiction of the mightiest battle in war history, with a human life toll of 20 million Russians and 10 million Germans, becomes more than a first hand record of war; it is also an ode to a people’s courage and self sacrifice, and the end of Hitler’s “Mein Kampf”. Historic film sequences of “The Seige of Leningrad” features the miracle of a “frozen lake” which becomes a rescue highway for a city surrounded and doomed, an event which turned the tide of World War II.

results.title: A Woman under the influence
results.brief_description: The title of this film refers to a wife and mother, Mabel Longhetti, who moves completely under the influence of her family and other people. She tries so hard to perform and conform, according to what she perceives they want, but she just comes across as “crazy” and the family are embarrassed. In the confusion, the film makes Mabel an expressive centre, focusing on the commotion she causes and the forms of agitation that extend across her face and body.

results.title: Faces
results.brief_description: “Faces” concentrates on two scenarios, one where middle-aged businessmen cheat on their wives and the other where the wives bring home a younger man from a nightclub. Both wives and husbands take turns in testing the novelty of the situations, initially improvising to bridge the awkwardness but then risking more and more. While the night out feels liberating, it ends up tearing painfully at their conservative personas.

results.title: Shadows
results.brief_description:
‘Shadows’ was a vanguard work of the independent American cinema, a bittersweet comedy centred on three African-American outsiders - Lelia and his two jazz-musicians brothers living in Greenwich Village - two of whom pass for white and all are part of the late fifties ‘lost generation’. We follow Lelia through three brief romantic involvements. Although the film was recognised at the time for its treatment of race, Cassavetes saw this as incidental to the wider question of identity. His special commitment to expression through performance and a concomitant openness of form give his films a rough, uninflected, anecdotal quality (a form of ‘fictional cinema
verite’). ‘Shadows’, like other Cassavetes’ films was fully scripted despite the reference in the end title to the film as ‘an improvisation’.
Cast includes Lelia Goldoni, Ben Carruthers, Hugh Hurd.

results.title: Opening night
results.brief_description: Myrtle Gordon is a successful actress who finds the part she has taken in a new play, about a “defeated, older woman”, humiliating. When a young fan is killed outside the theatre one night, Myrtle uses the experience of the girl and the accident to revisit her youth. While she searches for a vantage-point to perform the part, the film shows how the play and the world behind the play interact and threaten to draw her into collapse. Also available on VHS [310942].
